Detailed Description

template<int size, class T = double> template class ColumnVector

The class ColumnVector represents column vectors.

The class ColumnVector is derived from the base classes Matrix and VectorBase.

The class ColumnVector defines the data type ColumnVector and provides methods for operations such as cross product, dot product and element-by-element multiplication.

Example Program: 

//========================================================================
// Project: Robotic Platform
// ----------------------------------------------------------------------
// Package      : The Math Library
// Authors      : Vilas Kumar Chitrakaran
// Start Date   : Wed Dec 20 11:08:28 GMT 2000
// Compiler     : GNU c++
// Operating System : QNX RTP
// ----------------------------------------------------------------------
// File: Vector.t.cpp
// Example program for the vector classes.
//========================================================================

//========================================================================
// Vector.t.cpp
//------------------------------------------------------------------------
// \brief
// The file Vector.t.cpp is an example program that tests the vector
// related functions provided in the Math Library for the Robotic Platform.
//
//========================================================================


// ----- Standard Libaries -----

#include <iostream.h>

// ----- QRTS Libraries -----

// ----- Project Includes -----

#include "RowVector.hpp"
#include "ColumnVector.hpp"
#include "Vector.hpp"


int main()
{
  RowVector<3> R1;
  RowVector<3> R2;
  RowVector<3> R3;

    // Two row-vector objects with elements
    // of type double (default).

  ColumnVector<3> C1;
  ColumnVector<3> C2;
  ColumnVector<3> C3;

    // Two column-vector objects with elements
    // of type double (default).

  VectorBase<> &refV1 = C1;
  VectorBase<> &refV2 = R1;
    // Two references to objects of type VectorBase, 
    // the base class of ColumnVector and Rowvector.

  char a; 
    //some dummy dumbo.

//========================================================
// Input to vectors.
//--------------------------------------------------------
// Input all elements of the vector separated by whitespace
// using overloaded istream operator >>.
//  or
// Assign elements individually using overloaded () operator.
//  or
// You can also initialize a vector 
// directly, for example, 
// RowVector<3> R = 1,4,5;
//-------------------------------------------------------- 

  R1 = 23,67.9998, 86.2528;
  C2 = 543, 656, 9.999;
  // Initializing vectors directy.

  cout << "Input row-vector R2: " << endl;
  cin >> R2;

  
  cout << "Input column-vector C1: " << endl;
  cin >> C1;


//========================================================
// Output of the elements of the vector.
//--------------------------------------------------------
// The elements are output row-wise, separated by 
// white-space.
//======================================================== 

  cout << " The Column vector C1: \n" << C1 << endl;
  cout << " The Row vector R1: \n" << R1 << endl;

//========================================================
// Simple arithmetic operations on vectors.
//--------------------------------------------------------
// Arithmetic operations between vectors are performed 
// as in MATLAB. There is no need to do operations at the
// individual element level.
//========================================================

C3 = C1 + C2; //Addition
cout << "C1 + C2: \n" << C3 << endl;

C3 = C1 - C2; //Subtraction...if you didn't guess.
cout << "C1 - C2: \n" << C3 << endl;

C3 = 2.345*C1; //Premultiplication by a scalar
cout <<  "2.345*C1: \n "<< C3 << endl;
C3 = C1*2.345; //Postmultiplication by a scalar
cout <<  "C1*2.345: \n "<< C3 << endl;

C3 = C1/2.345; //Division by a scalar
cout <<  "C1/2.345: \n "<< C3 << endl;
cin >> a;

//And the transpose of a column is a row.
R3 = transpose(C1);
cout <<  "transpose(C1): \n "<< R3 << endl;
cin >> a;

//============================================
// To find the component of C1 along C2
//============================================

double component;
component = dotProduct(C1, C2);
cout << "dotProduct(C1, C2): " << component << endl;
cin >> a;

//=============================================
// find a vector in a direction normal to C1 and C2
//=============================================

ColumnVector<3> normal;
normal = crossProduct(C1, C2);
cout << "crossProduct(C1, C2): " << normal << endl;
cin >> a;

// ColumnVector is defined only for 3 dimensional vectors.
// You will cause a compiler error if you try to find
// cross-product of vectors of size not equal to 3.

//================================================
// do this if you want to do element-by-element 
// multiplication.
//================================================

ColumnVector<3> anotherVector;
anotherVector = elementProduct(C1, C2);
cout << "elementProduct(C1, C2): " << anotherVector << endl;
cin >> a;

//===================================================
// operations with base-classes
//===================================================

// An object of the base class VectorBase<> can be 
// instantiated and referenced to a ColumnVector or RowVector object.

VectorBase<> &RefV1 = C1;

// And you can assign between a vector object and a VectorBase object if both are same type (column or row vector) and have the same dimensions.

C2 = RefV1; 
//C2 now has values of C1.

cout << "C2: " << C2 << endl;

// The same operations are also possible with Row-vectors.

VectorBase<> &RefV2 = R1;
R2 = RefV2; 
cout << "R2: " << R2 << endl;

// The values in a vector can be modified by playing with the reference to that vector
RefV2 = 0; // Initializing all elments in R1 to 0;
cout << "R1 after initializing all it's elements through it's reference: "<< R1<<endl;

RefV2 = 66.66, 77.77, 8; // Initializing all elments in R1 to 0;
cout << "R1 after initializing it to a new set of values through it's reference: "<< R1<<endl;
cin >> a;

// output the elements of a VectorBase object
cout << "The elements of RefV1: ";
RefV1.output();
cout << "\n";

//===========================================
// The Vector object.
//===========================================

// A Vector object is by default a ColumnVector 
// and hence all operations possible on a ColumnVector
// is possible on a Vector object.

Vector<3> vector;
vector = 3.456, 4.927, 0.999;
vector = C1 + vector;
vector = vector/2.00;
vector = vector*5.98;
R1 = transpose(vector);
component = dotProduct(C1, vector);
normal = crossProduct(C1, vector);
double scalar;
scalar = R1 * vector;

// And after all those manipulations what do we have?
cout << "vector: " << vector<< endl;

return 0;
}

T & operator() ( int elementPosition ) [inline]
 

This function overloads the () operator to access the element at the elementPosition position of the vector. The operator can be intuitively used to assign a value to an element in the vector such as 

myVector(2)=12.65;
Parameters:
elementPosition   The index of the element in the vector.
Returns:
The value of the element at the specified position.

T operator() ( int elementPosition ) const [inline]
 

This function overloads the () operator to read the element at the elementPosition of the vector such as 

cout << myVector(2);
.
Parameters:
elementPosition   The index of the element in the vector.
Returns:
The value of the element at the specified position.

ColumnVector< size,T >& operator=<size, T> ( const VectorBase< T >& vectorBase ) [inline]
 

This function overloads the assignment operator to assign a VectorBase type to a ColumnVector type. Both objects must have the same dimensions.

Parameters:
vectorBase   The object of the base class VectorBase.

Reimplemented from VectorBase.

Reimplemented in Vector.

MatrixInitializer< T > operator=<T> ( const T & elementValue ) [virtual]
 

This function provides an overloaded assignment operator to initialize a vector object.

Parameters:
elementValue   The value to which all elements in the vector are initialized. The initialization of the vector object can also be done as a comma seperated list. For example: 
ColumnVector<3> myVector;
         myVector = 67.88, 45.89, 90;

Reimplemented from Matrix.

Reimplemented in Vector.
